<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 586, 598, 601]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 601, 606, 616]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 630, 608, 646]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 646, 756, 661]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 661, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
A statistics student asks people to complete a survey. The probability that a randomly chosen person agrees to complete the survey is 0.2. Find the probability that at least one of the first three people asked agrees to complete the survey.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Tien measured the arm lengths, \(x \text{cm}\), of 20 people in his class. He found that \(\Sigma x = 1218\) and the standard deviation of \(x\) was 4.2. Calculate \(\Sigma (x - 45)\) and \(\Sigma (x - 45)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
At the end of a revision course in mathematics, students have to pass a test to gain a certificate. The probability of any student passing the test at the first attempt is 0.85. Those students who fail are allowed to retake the test once, and the probability of any student passing the retake test is 0.65.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 641, 153]]<|/det|>
Draw a fully labelled tree diagram to show all the outcomes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 508, 156, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 508, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
Given that a student gains the certificate, find the probability that this student fails the test on the first attempt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|> The number of Olympic medals won in the 2012 Olympic Games by the top 27 countries is shown below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 114, 717, 173]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 191, 156, 209]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 191, 569, 210]]<|/det|> Draw a stem-and-leaf diagram to illustrate the data. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 192, 920, 210]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A car park has spaces for 18 cars, arranged in a line. On one day there are 5 cars, of different makes, parked in randomly chosen positions and 13 empty spaces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 722, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the number of possible arrangements of the 5 cars in the car park.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 330, 146, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 330, 670, 348]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the 5 cars are not all next to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 330, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
On another day, 12 cars of different makes are parked in the car park. 5 of these cars are red, 4 are white and 3 are black. Elizabeth selects 3 of these cars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 153, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the number of selections Elizabeth can make that include cars of at least 2 different colours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Josie aims to catch a bus which departs at a fixed time every day. Josie arrives at the bus stop \(T\) minutes before the bus departs, where \(T \sim \mathrm{N}(5.3, 2.1^2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 789, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Josie has to wait longer than 6 minutes at the bus stop.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Josie waits longer than \(x\) minutes on fewer than 3 days in 10 days. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 186, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 504, 522, 522]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Josie misses the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
